quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We see a significant amount of games. We find engineering teams that are very, very AI forward are reporting about eight to 10 hours save per week. Whenever I hear a stat like this, I think an important element is this is the worst it will ever be. This is now the baseline. The truth is the value is changing every day, so you need to ride that wave along with it.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Gives a concrete productivity data point and a mindset shift: treat current AI gains as a baseline that will keep improving, so organizations should continuously adapt.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You'll be talking to a colleague on Slack or an email, and they'll be discussing some feature that they think is useful to implement. Now a few hours later, he'll find that Goose has already tried to build that feature and opened a PR for it on Git.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A vivid example of an AI agent proactively turning casual discussion into working code, illustrating a new workflow where implementation starts automatically.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: What's been surprising and really amazing, the non-technical people using AI agents and programming tools to build things, the people that are able to embrace it to optimize for their particular workday and their particular set of tasks are really showing the most impact from these tools.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that engineers benefit most, pointing practitioners to enable non-technical teams with agents and tooling for outsized impact.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: All these LLMs are sitting idle overnight and on weekends, while humans aren't there. There's no need for that. They should be working all the time. They should be trying to build in anticipation of what we want.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Proposes an operational model where AI works continuously and proactively, reframing how teams can use off-hours compute to accelerate delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: A lot of engineers think that code quality is important to building a successful product. The two have nothing to do with each other.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A provocative claim that separates product success from engineering craftsmanship, useful for prioritization and team incentives.

quotes.topic_title: The AI manifesto letter to Jack Dorsey
quotes.text: So at some point, I observed that we were talking about lots of deep things, lots of relevant things, but no one was really paying attention to AI, and so that's when I wrote that letter.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Highlights a practical trigger for action: noticing a strategic blind spot in leadership discussions and intervening directly.

quotes.topic_title: The AI manifesto letter to Jack Dorsey
quotes.text: there wasn't much to the letter other than I think we should do this. I think we should do it centrally and it's important for us to be ahead of the game and be an AI native company because that's where the industry is heading.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A simple, centralized mandate to become “AI native” as an organizing principle—useful as a leadership-level framing for transformation.

quotes.topic_title: The AI manifesto letter to Jack Dorsey
quotes.text: So about two and a half years ago or so, Jack really felt like things needed to change.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Signals the importance of explicit change intent from the top as a prerequisite for major strategic shifts like AI adoption.

quotes.topic_title: The AI manifesto letter to Jack Dorsey
quotes.text: So he got about 40 of the company's top executives into a room on a weekly basis, and they all used to sort of talk everything through that was going on and he added me to that group.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A concrete operating cadence (weekly exec forum) that other companies can emulate to drive alignment and surface gaps like AI.

quotes.topic_title: The AI manifesto letter to Jack Dorsey
quotes.text: No, yeah, in fact, I was part-time at the time because I had just had a kid and I was coming back in and I was helping out one of the engineering teams and then Jack came over to Sydney and spent two days with me and both of us like long walks.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A counterintuitive story: major strategic influence (and career impact) can come from someone not in a formal leadership role—even part-time.

quotes.topic_title: Re-centering Block as a technology company
quotes.text: At the start, my main focus was to get block to think like a technology company.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A clear, actionable north star: explicitly reframe the company identity to drive culture and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Re-centering Block as a technology company
quotes.text: And for a long time we had had a little bit of, I'm going to call it identity drift, maybe.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A memorable diagnosis leaders can use to name and correct gradual misalignment between what a company is and how it behaves.

quotes.topic_title: Re-centering Block as a technology company
quotes.text: And so the first thing I did was to try and institute a number of programs that focused on that. So everything from getting the top ICs in the company together to talk to each other, to starting a whole bunch of special projects.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Concrete levers (IC convening + special projects) that practitioners can replicate to reboot a tech-first culture.

quotes.topic_title: Re-centering Block as a technology company
quotes.text: So we got about two to five engineers per project. There were about eight or nine different projects and we had reinstituted, the company-wide hack week.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Specific operating model details (small teams, multiple parallel bets, hack week) that make the approach implementable.

quotes.topic_title: Re-centering Block as a technology company
quotes.text: And so all of this just kind of created a little bit of a spark of, "Hey, we're building technology again, we're trying to push the frontier again."
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Captures the intended cultural effect: programs are designed to reignite momentum and ambition, not just ship features.

quotes.topic_title: GM to functional org restructure for AI
quotes.text: So I think that that was very useful for us for the stage of company that we were in, but when you really want to go deep in technology, when you really want to connect with these things that are industry changing events that are happening, you need a singular focus, and we changed the organization.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A clear heuristic for when a GM/portfolio structure stops working and a functional model becomes necessary to drive deep technical change (like AI).

quotes.topic_title: GM to functional org restructure for AI
quotes.text: So all engineers report into one single team now, all designers report into one single team and there's single head of engineering, single head of design, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A concrete, replicable org-design move: centralize engineering and design under functional leadership to enable shared strategy and execution.

quotes.topic_title: GM to functional org restructure for AI
quotes.text: So yeah, I would say to companies, find your DNA and really try to optimize for what that is in a very simple and clear way.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for choosing an operating model: align structure to the company’s core identity rather than copying a generic playbook.

quotes.topic_title: GM to functional org restructure for AI
quotes.text: I think that one of the things that I learned the most throughout this process is that Conway's Law can be really, really powerful. So it's the law that basically says you ship your org structure.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A memorable mental model linking organizational design directly to product/system outcomes—useful for motivating structural change.

quotes.topic_title: GM to functional org restructure for AI
quotes.text: We're all have access to the same tools, we share the same policies. So a certain level of senior engineer means the same thing across the whole company. People can move from one team to another's into an area of need.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Specific examples of what functional unification unlocks in practice: standardization, consistent leveling, and talent mobility to match shifting priorities.

quotes.topic_title: How engineering work changed with AI automation
quotes.text: In the small, certain teams that are very, very AI natives or teams that are building AI first everywhere are working much differently than before because they're using vibe code tools and they're essentially building without writing lines of code by hand, and that just wasn't true through the three years ago.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete shift in day-to-day engineering workflow for AI-native teams: building via AI tools rather than manual coding.

quotes.topic_title: How engineering work changed with AI automation
quotes.text: So that's dramatically different in teams that are still working with very heavy legacy code bases.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Offers a practical segmentation model: AI productivity gains vary sharply depending on how legacy-heavy the codebase is.

quotes.topic_title: How engineering work changed with AI automation
quotes.text: So we have these tools that run 24/7 or run in the CI pipeline and they're analyzing vulnerabilities.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Actionable example of “always-on” automation: embed AI agents into CI to continuously scan for security issues.

quotes.topic_title: How engineering work changed with AI automation
quotes.text: They're looking at even bugs filed on tickets and trying to build patches while engineers are asleep.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Concrete methodology: use background agents to turn bug reports into proposed fixes asynchronously, reducing cycle time.

quotes.topic_title: How engineering work changed with AI automation
quotes.text: different teams have adapted in different ways depending on how close they are to the tools.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A deployment insight: adoption and impact depend on tool proximity/access, implying org design and enablement matter.

quotes.topic_title: Measured AI productivity gains and where it works
quotes.text: So we look at PRs, we look at throughput of features, we look at a whole bunch of things and we have our data scientists come up with a complicated formula that tries to distill it all into something meaningful.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A practical measurement approach: validate self-reported AI gains with multiple operational metrics and a synthesized model.

quotes.topic_title: Measured AI productivity gains and where it works
quotes.text: And we feel across the whole company, we're probably trending towards 20 to 25% of manual hours saved.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A concrete company-wide benchmark for AI productivity impact that teams can compare against.

quotes.topic_title: Measured AI productivity gains and where it works
quotes.text: And the truth is the value is changing every day. And so you need to be adaptable and look at what the value is today and plan for what the value will be tomorrow and then slowly expand to the areas where it's most efficacious.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A mental model for AI adoption: treat it as a moving target and expand use cases iteratively where ROI is highest right now.

quotes.topic_title: Measured AI productivity gains and where it works
quotes.text: So this has been one of the most surprising and energizing uses of Goose within Block is we'll have our enterprise risk management team build a whole system for self-servicing enterprise risk, and this is compressing weeks of work into hours, or ordinarily, they would be waiting for an internal apps team or something to go and build that and they would put that on their Q2 roadmap and everyone would be twiddling their thumbs until it all clicked into place, but now you can just go and do it.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A vivid example of AI enabling non-technical teams to self-serve tooling, collapsing internal backlog delays and cycle time.

quotes.topic_title: Measured AI productivity gains and where it works
quotes.text: And so I think the companies that aren't feeling the success in AI are trying to just throw these tools at their giant code bases and hoping good things will happen, and that's not how it's playing out.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A contrarian warning: AI wins aren’t automatic in complex legacy codebases—use-case selection matters.

quotes.topic_title: Goose: Block’s open-source AI agent via MCP
quotes.text: That metric is across all teams. So that would be our support teams, our legal teams, our risk teams, all of them together.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Clarifies that AI impact measurement (hours saved) is being applied enterprise-wide, not just in engineering—useful for practitioners setting org-level KPIs.

quotes.topic_title: Goose: Block’s open-source AI agent via MCP
quotes.text: And so if you're building a totally new Greenfields code base or you're building an app for a new platform, then we're seeing those pretty aggressive gains, but in very complex code bases that already exist, those gains are not quite there yet.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A practical rule-of-thumb for where AI coding tools deliver the biggest ROI: greenfield/new-platform work vs. legacy complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Goose: Block’s open-source AI agent via MCP
quotes.text: So until that point, the LLMs were not really able to do much other than chat, but Goose gives these brains arms and legs to go out and act in our digital world, and that's where we find it's had most impact and it's built on this fairly open protocol that anyone can implement.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for moving from chat to action by connecting LLMs to tools via an open protocol (MCP).

quotes.topic_title: Goose: Block’s open-source AI agent via MCP
quotes.text: So one example that I really like is you can ask Goose to go and build your marketing report and it has MCPs to connect to Snowflake and Tableau and Looker.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Concrete example of an agent orchestrating real enterprise systems end-to-end, illustrating what “tool-connected” AI enables.

quotes.topic_title: Goose: Block’s open-source AI agent via MCP
quotes.text: But with Goose, that's no longer necessary with a few lines of code that an MCP represents. All these systems are orchestratable with AI basically overnight, and Goose can write its own MCPs. So it's pretty bootstrappable as well.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Counterintuitive operational takeaway: teams don’t need to wait on vendors for AI features—wrapping tools with MCP can enable rapid automation, even self-extending.

quotes.topic_title: Open-sourcing Goose and the origin story
quotes.text: Yeah, and we have a lot of companies using Goose pretty actively. I don't want to name too many names, but from our competitors to our close partners, a lot of them are using Goose pretty regularly on their teams. I know Databricks talks about it a lot, but everyone you can think of in this mid-tech tier is using Goose in some form.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Concrete adoption signal (including competitors) that validates open-sourcing as a way to drive broad ecosystem usage.

quotes.topic_title: Open-sourcing Goose and the origin story
quotes.text: Yeah, we believe in the power of open source and one of our core missions is to increase openness, and that means contributing to open protocols and contributing to open source.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A clear mission-driven framework for deciding to open-source: optimize for “increasing openness” via protocols and code.

quotes.topic_title: Open-sourcing Goose and the origin story
quotes.text: And as a tech company, we're built on a lot of open source software. I think pretty much every tech company is whether you're talking about Linux or Java or MySQL or any of these essential components, and so we feel like we have a strong imperative to give back.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Actionable reciprocity principle: if your stack depends on open source, treat contributing back as an organizational imperative.

quotes.topic_title: Open-sourcing Goose and the origin story
quotes.text: We want to build things that not only are good for us and our customers, but that outlast Block and outgrow Block, that's certainly a core value for us and has been from the beginning even long before this whole AI phase.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Memorable long-term product bar—build for durability and ecosystem growth beyond the company itself.

quotes.topic_title: Extreme workflows: Goose watching and acting proactively
quotes.text: And then a few hours later he'll find that Goose has already tried to build that feature and opened a PR for it on Git and all sorts of other wacky things like that.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Concrete example of an AI agent proactively turning ambient work context into shipped code (a PR) without explicit prompting.

quotes.topic_title: Extreme workflows: Goose watching and acting proactively
quotes.text: So it'll try to nudge him out of a workflow. If he's running over on a meeting and he's late for something else, it comes up with these creative things that he didn't program or he didn't write prompts for, but that it thinks will help him improve his productivity or improve his work day.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Shows a workflow model where the agent acts as an autonomous “productivity governor,” initiating interventions rather than waiting for commands.

quotes.topic_title: Extreme workflows: Goose watching and acting proactively
quotes.text: You have to have the stomach for it to be that level of tied into your working tools, but it kind of shows you what's possible with tools like this.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Highlights the key adoption barrier/tradeoff: deeper tool integration unlocks outsized leverage but requires higher trust and tolerance for risk.

quotes.topic_title: Extreme workflows: Goose watching and acting proactively
quotes.text: And Goose will automatically reschedule that meeting without him ever sitting in front of his calendar and clicking through 10 times.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Specific, immediately applicable automation target: delegating calendar conflict resolution end-to-end to an agent.

quotes.topic_title: Extreme workflows: Goose watching and acting proactively
quotes.text: Yeah, so these are things that I think we were waiting for the calendar vendor to build as features into calendar, but we don't need to do that anymore because AI is able to orchestrate this for us.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Counterintuitive shift in strategy: stop waiting on SaaS vendors for workflow features and instead use AI orchestration to bridge gaps across tools.

quotes.topic_title: Future of work: longer autonomy and overnight experiments
quotes.text: It's very ping pong. You do something, you wait for three or four minutes and it comes back with something sort of half-baked and you have to nudge it and guide it and massage it to get where it needs to be.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Highlights a limitation of today’s prompt/response workflow and motivates shifting to longer autonomous agent sessions.

quotes.topic_title: Future of work: longer autonomy and overnight experiments
quotes.text: So where we're working on a couple of experiments with Goose, with the next version of Goose where we're really trying to push it to work not just for two or three or five minutes at a time, our median session length is five minutes and on average, seven, but we're trying to push it to hours.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Provides a concrete benchmark (median/average session length) and an actionable target state (multi-hour sessions).

quotes.topic_title: Future of work: longer autonomy and overnight experiments
quotes.text: We're trying to say, "Hey, all these LLMs are sitting idle overnight and on weekends while humans aren't there, there's no need for that." They should be working all the time.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Introduces an operational model: treat agents as continuously running capacity that can execute work while teams are offline.

quotes.topic_title: Future of work: longer autonomy and overnight experiments
quotes.text: We need instead to be able to describe multiple different experiments in a great amount of detail. And then maybe we go to sleep and then in the morning, all those experiments are built and we can sort of throw away five or six of them.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A practical methodology for parallel prototyping: specify many experiments, let agents build overnight, then prune aggressively.

quotes.topic_title: Future of work: longer autonomy and overnight experiments
quotes.text: And one of the things I'm really pushing our teams to think about is what would our world look like if every single release, RM minus RF deleted the entire app and rebuilt it from scratch?
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A provocative mental model that challenges the “never rewrite” norm and reframes releases as potentially full regenerations.

quotes.topic_title: Human taste, portfolio judgment, and avoiding AI slop
quotes.text: I do think we're going to need a lot of human taste to anchor these AIs so they don't go off script to be honest.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A practical reminder that human judgment is a necessary control layer to keep AI outputs aligned with real user value.

quotes.topic_title: Human taste, portfolio judgment, and avoiding AI slop
quotes.text: And that's a differentiator that I think will push us beyond this era of AI slop that everyone's talking about.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Positions “tasteful” human-guided design as a competitive moat against low-quality AI-generated output.

quotes.topic_title: Human taste, portfolio judgment, and avoiding AI slop
quotes.text: And then as a human, you're sitting there thinking, "Is any of this necessary? If we just change the process, do we even need to think about building tools?"
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A reusable decision test: challenge whether tooling is needed at all before debating buy vs build.

quotes.topic_title: Human taste, portfolio judgment, and avoiding AI slop
quotes.text: And this is the thing that AI isn't good at, it's not able to have this portfolio judgment or judgment across a global sense of what's important and what matters.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Defines a clear boundary of AI capability—cross-team prioritization and global tradeoffs—where humans must lead.

quotes.topic_title: Human taste, portfolio judgment, and avoiding AI slop
quotes.text: The savings and costs that there might be in replacing a vendor tool by something you build in-house is probably not worth it in the mental bandwidth that you've lost and the amount of the team's technical focus that's being taken away.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Counterbalances “build with AI to save money” with an operational cost model centered on focus and cognitive load.

quotes.topic_title: Build vs buy and the hidden cost of maintenance
quotes.text: Yeah, I think people forget just how much maintenance it takes to keep something you've built. Like, "Okay, cool, we built it in a weekend and now it's years of endless maintenance and requests and support."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the hidden long-term cost of internal tools: maintenance and support can dwarf initial build time.

quotes.topic_title: Build vs buy and the hidden cost of maintenance
quotes.text: Yeah, it's the classic 80/20 problem, and we have that enough with the apps that we build for our customers.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Introduces a mental model for why most effort comes after the initial “working” version—especially in production systems.

quotes.topic_title: Build vs buy and the hidden cost of maintenance
quotes.text: So in Cash Card, for example, we built the entire functionality of Cash Card, I would say pretty much in a weekend or maybe a week of integration and work.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how quickly an MVP can be built relative to the long tail of real-world hardening.

quotes.topic_title: Build vs buy and the hidden cost of maintenance
quotes.text: And then it took a really long time to iron out all these edge cases where someone would tip twice the value of the bill and then it would completely break something in the back end, or people would use it as a gas station and they have a different way of billing your card.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Illustrates how edge cases (not core functionality) dominate maintenance cost and complexity over time.

quotes.topic_title: Build vs buy and the hidden cost of maintenance
quotes.text: And to your point, I would always come back to what is the reason we're doing this? Why does it matter to us and to our customers? And if it doesn't clearly satisfy that, I would just push it off as a not interesting thing.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization advice: tie build-vs-buy decisions to customer value and mission, and deprioritize the rest.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We talk a lot on this podcast about the amazing advances in ai, but this can be a double-edged sword.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable framing that encourages practitioners to plan for both the upside and abuse cases of AI.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: For every wow moment, there are fraudsters using the same tech to wreak havoc, laundering money, taking over employee identities and impersonating businesses.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete threat model and examples that teams can use to prioritize AI-era fraud defenses.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Best of all, Persona makes it easy to know who you're dealing with without adding friction for good users.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the practical product principle of balancing security with user experience to avoid harming legitimate users.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This is why leading platforms like Etsy, LinkedIn, Square and Lyft trust Persona to secure their platform persona is also offering my listeners 500 free services per month for one full year, just head to withpersona.com/lenny to get started, that's withpersona.com/lenny.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides specific examples of adopters plus a concrete promotional offer that may be actionable for listeners evaluating the tool.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring in an AI era: mindset over tool mastery
quotes.text: I don't think that things have progressed far enough that it's really impacted in a fundamental way how many people you would need to build an app of the scale of Cash App, for example.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Counters the assumption that AI has already materially reduced headcount needs for large-scale products.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring in an AI era: mindset over tool mastery
quotes.text: And I think that moving to a functional structure completely changes that and you're like, "Well, we can leverage common platforms, common modules, we can bring in experts from across the company to advise us on how better to do this."
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Offers an org-design-driven productivity model (platform reuse + shared expertise) as a bigger lever than adding engineers.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring in an AI era: mindset over tool mastery
quotes.text: But on the AI side, we're very much looking for people that are embracing these tools and that are eager to try and learn from it. We're not looking for people who are amazing AI practitioners on the get-go.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: Actionable hiring guidance: prioritize learning orientation and tool openness over immediate AI mastery.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring in an AI era: mindset over tool mastery
quotes.text: Yeah, a learning mindset is how I would put it. This is something that Jack our CEO talks about a lot is he wants us to be a learning first company.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A memorable hiring/operating principle that can be used as a north star for interview and culture design.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring in an AI era: mindset over tool mastery
quotes.text: It is massive, although I think that it's a little bit like the analogy of if you build a bigger highway, you'll just get more cars on the road.
quotes.speaker: Dhanji R. Prasanna
quotes.context: A sticky mental model for why AI-driven productivity can increase demand/throughput rather than reduce work.
